qas.question: Where was Rabbi Azriel Hildesheimer from?
what was the name of the Rabbi of Altona?
What was the name of the manifesto that Rabbi Jacob Ettlinger produced?
How many rabbi's signed on with the manifesto Jacob Ettlinger published?
Where was Rabbi Samson Raphael Hirsch from?

plausible_answers.text: a group of traditionalist German Jews

qas.question: What group supported a new temple in Hamburg?
Where did a group of orthodox Jews convene?
What was considered the first Reformed Jewish periodical?
Who fought against the strength and awareness of the Orthodox Jewry?

context: In reaction to the emergence of Reform Judaism, <b6_0>a group of traditionalist German Jews<b6_0/> emerged in support of some of the <b5_0>values of the Haskalah<b5_0/>, but also wanted to defend the classic, traditional interpretation of Jewish law and tradition. This group was led by those who opposed the establishment of a new temple in Hamburg , as reflected in the booklet "Ele Divrei HaBerit". As a group of Reform Rabbis convened in <b7_0>Braunschweig<b7_0/>, Rabbi <a1_0>Jacob Ettlinger<a1_0/> of Altona published a manifesto entitled "<a2_0>Shlomei Emunei Yisrael<a2_0/>" in German and Hebrew, having <a3_0>177<a3_0/> Rabbis sign on. At this time the first Orthodox Jewish periodical, "<b8_0>Der Treue Zions Waechter<b8_0/>", was launched with the Hebrew supplement "Shomer Zion HaNe'eman" [1845 - 1855]. In later years it was Rav Ettlinger's students <b9_0>Rabbi Samson<b9_0/> Raphael Hirsch and Rabbi Azriel Hildesheimer of <a0_0><a4_0>Berlin<a4_0/><a0_0/> who deepened the awareness and strength of Orthodox Jewry. Rabbi Samson Raphael Hirsch commented in 1854:
